title: Cybernetic Marionette: Channeling Collective Agency Through a Wearable Robot in a Live Dancer-Robot Duet
summary:
We describe DANCE^2, an interactive dance performance in which audience
members channel their collective agency into a dancer-robot duet by voting on
the behavior of a wearable robot affixed to the dancer's body. At key moments
during the performance, the audience is invited to either continue the
choreography or override it, shaping the unfolding interaction through
real-time collective input. While post-performance surveys revealed that
participants felt their choices meaningfully influenced the performance, voting
data across four public performances exhibited strikingly consistent patterns.
This tension between what audience members do, what they feel, and what
actually changes highlights a complex interplay between agentive behavior, the
experience of agency, and power. We reflect on how choreography, interaction
design, and the structure of the performance mediate this relationship,
offering a live analogy for algorithmically curated digital systems where
agency is felt, but not exercised.

AI.tldr: DANCEÂ² is an interactive dance where the audience influences a dancer-robot duet through real-time voting, revealing complexities in agency and interaction design.
AI.motivation: To explore the dynamics of audience agency in an interactive dance performance and its implications for choreography and interaction design.
AI.method: Audience members vote on the behavior of a wearable robot during key moments of a dance performance, collecting both qualitative surveys and quantitative voting data.
AI.result: Post-performance surveys indicated participants felt their choices significantly impacted the performance, while voting patterns showed surprising consistency across events.
AI.conclusion: The performance reveals the nuanced relationship between perceived agency, actual influence, and the design of interactive systems, suggesting insights applicable to algorithmically curated digital experiences.
key_contributions: Demonstration of audience agency in performance art
Analysis of real-time voting impact on interaction
Reflection on design implications for digital systems
AI.limitations: The study is based on limited performances and may not generalize to broader contexts.

title: Mastery Learning Improves Performance on Complex Tasks on PCP Literacy Test
summary:
Developing literacy with unfamiliar data visualization techniques such as
Parallel Coordinate Plots (PCPs) can be a significant challenge for students.
We adopted the Revised Bloom's taxonomy to instruct students on Parallel
Coordinate Plots (PCPs) using Mastery Learning in the classroom. To evaluate
Mastery Learning's impact, we conducted an intervention in a Data Visualization
course to teach students about PCPs using the Revised Bloom's taxonomy with and
without Mastery Learning. Based on our intervention, we found that while
students in both groups performed similarly on the first two (Remember,
Understand) modules, the students in the Mastery Learning group performed
better on modules that required more advanced thinking (Analyze, Evaluate) and
demonstrated a better comprehension of PCPs. We provide all the materials
developed including the six-module Bloom's Taxonomy PCP literacy (BTPL) test
for full reproducibility on our website at
https://vis-graphics.github.io/PCP-Literacy-Test/.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the effectiveness of Mastery Learning in teaching Parallel Coordinate Plots (PCPs) using Revised Bloom's Taxonomy in a Data Visualization course.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges students face in developing literacy with unfamiliar data visualization techniques, specifically PCPs.
AI.method: An intervention was conducted comparing two groups of students in a Data Visualization course: one using Mastery Learning and the other following a standard approach, focusing on their performance across different cognitive levels of Bloom's Taxonomy.
AI.result: Students in the Mastery Learning group scored higher in advanced modules (Analyze, Evaluate) compared to those in the standard group, indicating better comprehension of PCPs.
AI.conclusion: Mastery Learning enhances the understanding of complex concepts like PCPs by promoting deeper cognitive engagement in students.
key_contributions: Introduction of Mastery Learning to teach data visualization techniques
Evaluation of its effectiveness through Bloom's Taxonomy
Provision of educational materials for reproducibility

title: Intergenerational AI Literacy in Korean Immigrant Families: Interpretive Gatekeeping Meets Convenient Critical Deferment
summary:
As artificial intelligence (AI) becomes deeply integrated into family life,
immigrant families must navigate unique intergenerational, linguistic, and
cultural challenges. This study examines how Korean immigrant families in the
United States negotiate the use of AI tools such as ChatGPT and smart
assistants in their homes. Through 20 semi-structured interviews with parents
and teens, we identify two key practices that shape their engagement:
interpretive gatekeeping, where parents mediate their children's AI use through
a lens of cultural and ethical values, and convenient critical deferment, where
teens strategically postpone critical evaluation of AI for immediate academic
and social utility. These intertwined practices challenge conventional,
skills-based models of AI literacy, revealing it instead as a dynamic and
relational practice co-constructed through ongoing family negotiation. We
contribute to information science and HCI by offering a new conceptual
extension for intergenerational AI literacy and providing design implications
for more equitable, culturally attuned, and family-centered AI systems.

AI.tldr: This study explores how Korean immigrant families in the U.S. use AI tools, highlighting practices that shape engagement and suggesting design implications for equitable AI systems.
AI.motivation: To understand how immigrant families negotiate AI tools in the context of intergenerational, linguistic, and cultural challenges.
AI.method: Conducted 20 semi-structured interviews with parents and teens from Korean immigrant families.
AI.result: Identified two practices: interpretive gatekeeping by parents and convenient critical deferment by teens, affecting AI engagement.
AI.conclusion: AI literacy is a dynamic and relational practice informed by family negotiation rather than a purely skills-based approach.
key_contributions: Introduction of interpretive gatekeeping and convenient critical deferment practices
Conceptual extension for intergenerational AI literacy
Design implications for equitable and culturally attuned AI systems.

title: Speculative Design in Spiraling Time: Methods and Indigenous HCI
comment:
3 pages, 1 figure, presented at the "Weaving Indigeneity and Culture
  into the Fabric of HCI Futures" Workshop at CHI '25
summary:
In this position paper, we first discuss the uptake of speculative design as
a method for Indigenous HCI. Then, we outline how a key assumption about
temporality threatens to undermine the usefulness of speculative design in this
context. Finally, we briefly sketch out a possible alternative understanding of
speculative design, based on the concept of "spiraling time," which could be
better suited for Indigenous HCI.

AI.tldr: This position paper examines the role of speculative design in Indigenous human-computer interaction (HCI) and proposes an alternative perspective on temporality relevant to this context.
AI.motivation: To explore how speculative design can be effectively utilized in Indigenous HCI and to address the limitations posed by traditional notions of temporality.
AI.method: The paper discusses the concept of speculative design in Indigenous contexts and critiques the prevailing assumption about temporality's application in such scenarios.
AI.result: The paper proposes the idea of 'spiraling time' as a more fitting temporal framework for Indigenous HCI practices.
AI.conclusion: Redefining temporality in speculative design could enhance its applicability and relevance in Indigenous HCI.
key_contributions: Discussion on the relevance of speculative design for Indigenous HCI.
Critique of traditional temporality in design methodologies.
Introduction of 'spiraling time' as a new conceptual framework.

title: A Survey of Automatic Evaluation Methods on Text, Visual and Speech Generations
summary:
Recent advances in deep learning have significantly enhanced generative AI
capabilities across text, images, and audio. However, automatically evaluating
the quality of these generated outputs presents ongoing challenges. Although
numerous automatic evaluation methods exist, current research lacks a
systematic framework that comprehensively organizes these methods across text,
visual, and audio modalities. To address this issue, we present a comprehensive
review and a unified taxonomy of automatic evaluation methods for generated
content across all three modalities; We identify five fundamental paradigms
that characterize existing evaluation approaches across these domains. Our
analysis begins by examining evaluation methods for text generation, where
techniques are most mature. We then extend this framework to image and audio
generation, demonstrating its broad applicability. Finally, we discuss
promising directions for future research in cross-modal evaluation
methodologies.

AI.tldr: This paper reviews and categorizes automatic evaluation methods for generative AI across text, image, and audio modalities, proposing a unified taxonomy and identifying research directions.
AI.motivation: To systematically organize and evaluate the various methods of automatic evaluation for generated outputs in different modalities, addressing the gap in the existing literature.
AI.method: The paper presents a comprehensive review of automatic evaluation methods, organizing them into a unified taxonomy that identifies five fundamental paradigms used across text, image, and audio generative tasks.
AI.result: The framework highlights the maturity of text generation evaluation methods and extends its analysis to image and audio generation, demonstrating the applicability of the identified paradigms across modalities.
AI.conclusion: The paper discusses future research directions in cross-modal evaluation methodologies to enhance the quality assessment of generative AI outputs.
key_contributions: Comprehensive review of automatic evaluation methods for generative AI.
Unified taxonomy of evaluation approaches across text, image, and audio modalities.
Identification of five fundamental paradigms characterizing existing methodologies.

title: Extended Creativity: A Conceptual Framework for Understanding Human-AI Creative Relations
comment:
36 pages, 3 figures. This conceptual paper proposes a taxonomy of
  Extended Creativity systems and examines the relational dynamics between
  human and AI agents in creative processes. Suitable for readers in HCI, AI,
  cognitive science, and digital design. The illustrations were created by
  Francesco Giordano and are used with permission (not under CC license)
summary:
Artificial Intelligence holds significant potential to enhance human
creativity. However, achieving this vision requires a clearer understanding of
how such enhancement can be effectively realized. Adopting the perspective of
distributed creativity, we identify three primary modes through which AI can
contribute to creative processes: Support, where AI acts as a tool; Synergy,
where AI and humans collaborate in complementary ways; and Symbiosis, where
human and AI cognition become so integrated that they form a unified creative
system. These modes are defined along two key dimensions: the level of
technical autonomy exhibited by the AI system and the degree of perceived
agency attributed to it. We examine how each configuration influences different
levels of creativity - from everyday problem-solving to paradigm-shifting
innovation - and discuss the theoretical, ethical, and design implications.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a taxonomy of how AI can enhance creativity by examining three modes of interaction between AI and humans: Support, Synergy, and Symbiosis.
AI.motivation: To better understand how AI can enhance human creativity through different forms of interaction.
AI.method: The authors adopt a conceptual framework to define and categorize the modes of creativity enhancement by AI, examining their implications.
AI.result: The modes of Support, Synergy, and Symbiosis influence levels of creativity, from problem-solving to innovation, with varied ethical and design implications.
AI.conclusion: Understanding these modes can guide the development of AI systems that effectively augment human creativity while considering theoretical, ethical, and design dimensions.
key_contributions: Proposes a taxonomy of AI's role in enhancing creativity.
Examines the relational dynamics between human and AI agents in creative processes.
Discusses implications across theoretical, ethical, and design dimensions.
AI.limitations: The paper does not present empirical studies to validate the proposed modes; it is mainly conceptual.

title: TaskCraft: Automated Generation of Agentic Tasks
summary:
Agentic tasks, which require multi-step problem solving with autonomy, tool
use, and adaptive reasoning, are becoming increasingly central to the
advancement of NLP and AI. However, existing instruction data lacks tool
interaction, and current agentic benchmarks rely on costly human annotation,
limiting their scalability. We introduce \textsc{TaskCraft}, an automated
workflow for generating difficulty-scalable, multi-tool, and verifiable agentic
tasks with execution trajectories. TaskCraft expands atomic tasks using
depth-based and width-based extensions to create structurally and
hierarchically complex challenges. Empirical results show that these tasks
improve prompt optimization in the generation workflow and enhance supervised
fine-tuning of agentic foundation models. We present a large-scale synthetic
dataset of approximately 36,000 tasks with varying difficulty to support future
research on agent tuning and evaluation.

AI.tldr: TaskCraft is a workflow for generating scalable, multi-tool, and verifiable agentic tasks to improve NLP and AI capabilities.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of existing instruction data and benchmarks in agentic tasks that require interaction and autonomy.
AI.method: TaskCraft creates complex challenges by expanding atomic tasks through depth-based and width-based extensions, generating a synthetic dataset of approximately 36,000 tasks.
AI.result: Empirical studies demonstrate that TaskCraft's generated tasks improve prompt optimization and enhance supervised fine-tuning of agentic foundation models.
AI.conclusion: The large-scale dataset generated by TaskCraft supports future research on agent tuning and evaluation in NLP and AI.
key_contributions: Introduction of TaskCraft for generating scalable agentic tasks
Creation of a synthetic dataset of 36,000 tasks
Improvement in prompt optimization and fine-tuning of models.
AI.limitations: The system may still require validation against real-world tasks and scenarios.

title: Beyond Compliance: A User-Autonomy Framework for Inclusive and Customizable Web Accessibility
summary:
This paper proposes a shift from compliance-centered web accessibility to a
care-driven model that prioritizes user autonomy, using neurodivergent users as
a catalyst case for broader personalization needs. While accessibility
standards offer a flexible framework, they are often interpreted and
implemented as static compliance checklists, our approach reframes it as a
flexible, user-centered process. We introduce a customizable Comfort Mode
framework that allows users to adapt interface settings, such as contrast,
typography, motion, and scaling, according to their individual needs, while
retaining the brand's core visual identity. Grounded in psychological and
cognitive accessibility principles, our design supports personalization without
sacrificing creative freedom. We present both minimal and advanced
implementation models with mock-ups, demonstrating how inclusive design can be
seamlessly integrated at minimal cost. This approach aims to broaden digital
inclusivity by offering autonomy to those who require it, without imposing
changes on those who do not. The proposed system is adaptable, scalable, and
suitable for a wide range of users and brands, offering a new paradigm where
user autonomy, aesthetic integrity, and accessibility converge not through
compromise, but through choice.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a user-centered approach to web accessibility, focusing on personalization for neurodivergent users through the Comfort Mode framework, which allows users to adjust interface settings without compromising brand identity.
AI.motivation: To shift from compliance-centered web accessibility to a care-driven model that prioritizes user autonomy and personalization.
AI.method: The paper presents a customizable Comfort Mode framework that allows users to adapt interface settings such as contrast, typography, motion, and scaling according to their needs while retaining the brand's core visual identity.
AI.result: Demonstration of minimal and advanced implementation models with mock-ups showing how this inclusive design can be integrated at minimal cost.
AI.conclusion: The proposed system promotes digital inclusivity by offering autonomy to users who require it without imposing changes on others, allowing for a convergence of user autonomy, aesthetic integrity, and accessibility through choice.
key_contributions: Introduction of Comfort Mode framework for personalization
Grounding in psychological and cognitive accessibility principles
Demonstration of low-cost integration of inclusive design

title: A quantum semantic framework for natural language processing
comment: 12 pages, 2 figures, accepted submission to Quantum AI and NLP 2025
summary:
Semantic degeneracy represents a fundamental property of natural language
that extends beyond simple polysemy to encompass the combinatorial explosion of
potential interpretations that emerges as semantic expressions increase in
complexity. Large Language Models (LLMs) and other modern NLP systems face
inherent limitations precisely because they operate within natural language
itself, making them subject to the same interpretive constraints imposed by
semantic degeneracy. In this work, we argue using Kolmogorov complexity that as
an expression's complexity grows, the likelihood of any interpreting agent
(human or LLM-powered AI) recovering the single intended meaning vanishes. This
computational intractability suggests the classical view that linguistic forms
possess meaning in and of themselves is flawed. We alternatively posit that
meaning is instead actualized through an observer-dependent interpretive act.
To test this, we conducted a semantic Bell inequality test using diverse LLM
agents as ``computational cognitive systems'' to interpret ambiguous word pairs
under varied contextual settings. Across several independent experiments, we
found average CHSH expectation values ranging from 1.2 to 2.8, with several
runs yielding values (e.g., 2.3-2.4) that significantly violate the classical
boundary ($|S|\leq2$). This demonstrates that linguistic interpretation under
ambiguity can exhibit non-classical contextuality, consistent with results from
human cognition experiments. These results inherently imply that classical
frequentist-based analytical approaches for natural language are necessarily
lossy. Instead, we propose that Bayesian-style repeated sampling approaches can
provide more practically useful and appropriate characterizations of linguistic
meaning in context.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the issue of semantic degeneracy in natural language, asserting that as complexity increases, LLMs struggle to recover intended meanings. It tests this with LLMs via a semantic Bell inequality test, suggesting Bayesian approaches may better characterize meaning.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of LLMs in interpreting complex natural language due to semantic degeneracy, and challenge the classical view of meaning in linguistic forms.
AI.method: Utilized Kolmogorov complexity and conducted a semantic Bell inequality test with various LLM agents interpreting ambiguous word pairs in different contexts.
AI.result: Found average CHSH expectation values between 1.2 to 2.8, with some experiments significantly violating classical bounds, indicating non-classical contextuality in linguistic interpretation.
AI.conclusion: This suggests the inadequacy of classical frequentist approaches, advocating for Bayesian methods to better characterize linguistic meaning in context.
key_contributions: Demonstration of non-classical contextuality in LLM interpretation of ambiguous language.
Proposed shift from frequentist to Bayesian analytical frameworks for understanding linguistic meaning.
Experimental validation of theoretical claims regarding semantic degeneracy and interpretation.

title: IDEA: Augmenting Design Intelligence through Design Space Exploration
summary:
Design spaces serve as a conceptual framework that enables designers to
explore feasible solutions through the selection and combination of design
elements. However, effective decision-making remains heavily dependent on the
designer's experience, and the absence of mathematical formalization prevents
computational support for automated design processes. To bridge this gap, we
introduce a structured representation that models design spaces with orthogonal
dimensions and discrete selectable elements. Building on this model, we present
IDEA, a decision-making framework for augmenting design intelligence through
design space exploration to generate effective outcomes. Specifically, IDEA
leverages large language models (LLMs) for constraint generation, incorporates
a Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) algorithm guided by these constraints to
explore the design space efficiently, and instantiates abstract decisions into
domain-specific implementations. We validate IDEA in two design scenarios:
data-driven article composition and pictorial visualization generation,
supported by example results, expert interviews, and a user study. The
evaluation demonstrates the IDEA's adaptability across domains and its
capability to produce superior design outcomes.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces IDEA, a decision-making framework that enhances design intelligence by modeling design spaces and leveraging LLMs and MCTS for effective outcomes.
AI.motivation: To improve decision-making in design processes through a structured representation of design spaces and computational support using AI techniques.
AI.method: IDEA employs a structured model of design spaces with orthogonal dimensions and discrete elements, leveraging LLMs for constraint generation and a Monte Carlo Tree Search algorithm for design exploration.
AI.result: IDEA was validated through two design scenarios, demonstrating its adaptability and capability to produce superior design outcomes compared to conventional methods.
AI.conclusion: The findings illustrate that IDEA can effectively enhance design decision-making and outcomes across various domains.
key_contributions: Development of a structured representation of design spaces
Introduction of the IDEA framework that integrates LLMs and MCTS
Validation of IDEA through real-world design tasks
AI.limitations: The framework's effectiveness may vary depending on domain-specific constraints and the quality of the input data.

title: Chat-of-Thought: Collaborative Multi-Agent System for Generating Domain Specific Information
summary:
This paper presents a novel multi-agent system called Chat-of-Thought,
designed to facilitate the generation of Failure Modes and Effects Analysis
(FMEA) documents for industrial assets. Chat-of-Thought employs multiple
collaborative Large Language Model (LLM)-based agents with specific roles,
leveraging advanced AI techniques and dynamic task routing to optimize the
generation and validation of FMEA tables. A key innovation in this system is
the introduction of a Chat of Thought, where dynamic, multi-persona-driven
discussions enable iterative refinement of content. This research explores the
application domain of industrial equipment monitoring, highlights key
challenges, and demonstrates the potential of Chat-of-Thought in addressing
these challenges through interactive, template-driven workflows and
context-aware agent collaboration.

AI.tldr: Chat-of-Thought is a multi-agent system using collaborative LLMs to generate and validate FMEA documents for industrial assets.
AI.motivation: To optimize the generation and validation of FMEA tables through collaborative LLM-based agents.
AI.method: The system employs multiple agents with specific roles, facilitating dynamic task routing and iterative refinement of content via multi-persona discussions.
AI.result: Demonstrates the potential for improved FMEA generation through interactive workflows and contextual agent collaboration.
AI.conclusion: Chat-of-Thought effectively addresses challenges in industrial equipment monitoring by enhancing collaborative documentation processes.
key_contributions: Introduction of multi-agent system for FMEA creation
Dynamic persona-driven discussions for iterative content refinement
Context-aware workflows for industrial applications

title: Accessible Design in Integrated Development Environments: A Think Aloud Study Exploring the Experiences of Students with ADHD
summary:
Coding forms a key part of computer science education in universities. As
part of this education, Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) are
essential tools for coding. However, it is currently unknown how the design of
an IDE's interface impacts on students with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity
Disorder (ADHD).
  In this study we investigated the use of IDEs by students with ADHD. We
conducted a think aloud study with nine university computing students, followed
by qualitative observational interviews to analyse their learning and
engagement with the Visual Studio Code IDE. The paper reports on these
experiences and seeks to understand the role IDEs play in the educational
setting.
  Our work also examines how digital accessibility and usability are considered
in the current design of IDEs. We analysed the qualitative data using a
thematic analysis and identified three primary themes: self-confidence,
interaction, and learning as well as various sub-themes.
  The themes and their sub-themes illustrate key areas of consideration when
designing IDEs for students with ADHD. The primary findings highlight
experiences of frustration and barriers in the current design and layout of
IDEs.
  Through our participatory approach we provide a rare insight into ADHD user
experiences around usability and accessibility, and describe the need for
better design of development environments to ensure a positive learning
experience for the students.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates how Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) affect university students with ADHD, identifying key usability and accessibility issues.
AI.motivation: To explore the impact of IDE design on students with ADHD in computer science education, as their learning experiences are under-researched.
AI.method: We conducted a think aloud study with nine university computing students, followed by qualitative observational interviews to analyze their interactions with Visual Studio Code.
AI.result: The analysis revealed three main themes (self-confidence, interaction, and learning) along with various sub-themes indicating frustration and barriers in current IDE designs.
AI.conclusion: The findings underscore the necessity for improved IDE designs to enhance usability and accessibility for students with ADHD, ultimately fostering better learning experiences.
key_contributions: Insights into ADHD user experiences with IDEs
Identification of key themes affecting learning in IDEs
Recommendations for improved design of development environments
AI.limitations: The study's sample size is small, limiting generalizability to all students with ADHD.

title: When Meaning Stays the Same, but Models Drift: Evaluating Quality of Service under Token-Level Behavioral Instability in LLMs
comment:
This paper was developed for presentation at ICML 2025 Tokshop
  Workshop, but is now submitted as a standalone contribution
summary:
We investigate how large language models respond to prompts that differ only
in their token-level realization but preserve the same semantic intent, a
phenomenon we call prompt variance. We propose Prompt-Based Semantic Shift
(PBSS), a diagnostic framework for measuring behavioral drift in LLMs under
semantically equivalent prompt rewordings. Applied to ten constrained tasks,
PBSS reveals consistent, model-specific response shifts, suggesting statistical
regularities linked to tokenization and decoding. These results highlight an
overlooked dimension of model evaluation stability under rephrasing and suggest
that tokenization strategies and decoding dynamics may contribute to
post-training quality of service instability.

AI.tldr: Exploration of prompt variance and its impact on large language model responses using the PBSS framework.
AI.motivation: To understand how different token-level realizations of prompts affect the responses of large language models while maintaining the same semantic intent.
AI.method: Introduction of the Prompt-Based Semantic Shift (PBSS) framework to analyze behavioral drift across ten constrained tasks, examining variance in model-specific responses to semantically equivalent prompts.
AI.result: The PBSS framework revealed consistent and specific response shifts for various models, indicating that tokenization and decoding processes impact the stability of model responses to rephrased prompts.
AI.conclusion: The findings point to an overlooked aspect of model evaluation, emphasizing the role of tokenization and decoding strategies in the stability of language model responses post-training.
key_contributions: Development of the PBSS framework for analyzing prompt variance in LLMs
Demonstration of model-specific response shifts due to prompt rewording
Identification of potential issues in model stability linked to tokenization and decoding dynamics.
AI.limitations: The study is limited to ten constrained tasks and may not generalize to all LLM applications.

title: Integrating Large Language Models into Text Animation: An Intelligent Editing System with Inline and Chat Interaction
summary:
Text animation, a foundational element in video creation, enables efficient
and cost-effective communication, thriving in advertisements, journalism, and
social media. However, traditional animation workflows present significant
usability barriers for non-professionals, with intricate operational procedures
severely hindering creative productivity. To address this, we propose a Large
Language Model (LLM)-aided text animation editing system that enables real-time
intent tracking and flexible editing. The system introduces an agent-based
dual-stream pipeline that integrates context-aware inline suggestions and
conversational guidance as well as employs a semantic-animation mapping to
facilitate LLM-driven creative intent translation. Besides, the system supports
synchronized text-animation previews and parametric adjustments via unified
controls to improve editing workflow. A user study evaluates the system,
highlighting its ability to help non-professional users complete animation
workflows while validating the pipeline. The findings encourage further
exploration of integrating LLMs into a comprehensive video creation workflow.

AI.tldr: A novel LLM-aided text animation editing system that enhances usability for non-professionals by providing real-time editing support and inline suggestions.
AI.motivation: To address usability barriers in traditional text animation workflows for non-professionals, thereby enhancing creative productivity.
AI.method: The system utilizes an agent-based dual-stream pipeline integrating context-aware suggestions and conversational guidance, alongside semantic-animation mapping for intent translation.
AI.result: User study results demonstrate improved workflow efficiency and successful task completion for non-professional users using the system.
AI.conclusion: The LLM-aided system significantly enhances text animation editing for non-professional users, warranting further investigation into LLM integration in video creation.
key_contributions: Introduction of a dual-stream pipeline for text animation editing
Context-aware inline suggestions and conversational guidance
Validation of LLM-driven creative intent translation in editing workflows

title: ChartReasoner: Code-Driven Modality Bridging for Long-Chain Reasoning in Chart Question Answering
summary:
Recently, large language models have shown remarkable reasoning capabilities
through long-chain reasoning before responding. However, how to extend this
capability to visual reasoning tasks remains an open challenge. Existing
multimodal reasoning approaches transfer such visual reasoning task into
textual reasoning task via several image-to-text conversions, which often lose
critical structural and semantic information embedded in visualizations,
especially for tasks like chart question answering that require a large amount
of visual details. To bridge this gap, we propose ChartReasoner, a code-driven
novel two-stage framework designed to enable precise, interpretable reasoning
over charts. We first train a high-fidelity model to convert diverse chart
images into structured ECharts codes, preserving both layout and data semantics
as lossless as possible. Then, we design a general chart reasoning data
synthesis pipeline, which leverages this pretrained transport model to
automatically and scalably generate chart reasoning trajectories and utilizes a
code validator to filter out low-quality samples. Finally, we train the final
multimodal model using a combination of supervised fine-tuning and
reinforcement learning on our synthesized chart reasoning dataset and
experimental results on four public benchmarks clearly demonstrate the
effectiveness of our proposed ChartReasoner. It can preserve the original
details of the charts as much as possible and perform comparably with
state-of-the-art open-source models while using fewer parameters, approaching
the performance of proprietary systems like GPT-4o in out-of-domain settings.

AI.tldr: ChartReasoner is a two-stage framework that enhances visual reasoning over charts by converting chart images into structured ECharts codes and synthesizing reasoning trajectories for better interpretation.
AI.motivation: To improve visual reasoning capabilities of large language models, particularly in tasks that require understanding intricate details in charts, which are often lost in traditional image-to-text conversions.
AI.method: A high-fidelity model first converts chart images into structured ECharts codes, preserving layout and data semantics. A synthesis pipeline then generates chart reasoning trajectories and filters low-quality samples. Finally, a multimodal model is trained using both supervised fine-tuning and reinforcement learning.
AI.result: Experimental results show that ChartReasoner performs comparably to state-of-the-art models with fewer parameters and approaches the performance of proprietary systems like GPT-4o in out-of-domain settings.
AI.conclusion: ChartReasoner effectively maintains original chart details and enhances reasoning capabilities, demonstrating significant progress in multimodal reasoning tasks involving charts.
key_contributions: Development of a two-stage framework specifically for chart reasoning
Creation of a high-fidelity model for converting charts into structured codes
Introduction of a data synthesis pipeline for generating and validating chart reasoning samples.

title: Grasp Prediction based on Local Finger Motion Dynamics
summary:
The ability to predict the object the user intends to grasp offers essential
contextual information and may help to leverage the effects of point-to-point
latency in interactive environments. This paper explores the feasibility and
accuracy of real-time recognition of uninstrumented objects based on hand
kinematics during reach-to-grasp actions. In a data collection study, we
recorded the hand motions of 16 participants while reaching out to grasp and
then moving real and synthetic objects. Our results demonstrate that even a
simple LSTM network can predict the time point at which the user grasps an
object with a precision better than 21 ms and the current distance to this
object with a precision better than 1 cm. The target's size can be determined
in advance with an accuracy better than 97%. Our results have implications for
designing adaptive and fine-grained interactive user interfaces in ubiquitous
and mixed-reality environments.

AI.tldr: This paper examines the real-time prediction of user intentions during reach-to-grasp actions using hand kinematics.
AI.motivation: To enhance interactive environments by predicting user grasp intentions, addressing point-to-point latency issues.
AI.method: Data collection from 16 participants, analyzing hand motions while interacting with real and synthetic objects; utilized LSTM networks for prediction.
AI.result: Simple LSTM networks achieved grasp prediction with a precision of better than 21 ms and distance measurement to objects with a precision of better than 1 cm; size of the target object predicted with over 97% accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Findings suggest significant potential for improving adaptive user interfaces in ubiquitous and mixed-reality environments through effective grasp intention prediction.
key_contributions: Real-time prediction of grasp intentions based on hand kinematics
Demonstrated high precision in predicting grasp timing and distance
Implications for designing adaptive user interfaces in interactive environments

title: Unsupervised Elicitation of Language Models
summary:
To steer pretrained language models for downstream tasks, today's
post-training paradigm relies on humans to specify desired behaviors. However,
for models with superhuman capabilities, it is difficult or impossible to get
high-quality human supervision. To address this challenge, we introduce a new
unsupervised algorithm, Internal Coherence Maximization (ICM), to fine-tune
pretrained language models on their own generated labels, \emph{without
external supervision}. On GSM8k-verification, TruthfulQA, and Alpaca reward
modeling tasks, our method matches the performance of training on golden
supervision and outperforms training on crowdsourced human supervision. On
tasks where LMs' capabilities are strongly superhuman, our method can elicit
those capabilities significantly better than training on human labels. Finally,
we show that our method can improve the training of frontier LMs: we use our
method to train an unsupervised reward model and use reinforcement learning to
train a Claude 3.5 Haiku-based assistant. Both the reward model and the
assistant outperform their human-supervised counterparts.

AI.tldr: The paper presents Internal Coherence Maximization (ICM), an unsupervised algorithm for fine-tuning pretrained language models without external supervision, which matches or outperforms human-supervised methods on various tasks.
AI.motivation: To address the difficulty of obtaining high-quality human supervision for superhuman language models in post-training paradigms.
AI.method: Internal Coherence Maximization (ICM) fine-tunes language models using their own generated labels instead of relying on external supervision.
AI.result: ICM matches the performance of training on golden supervision and outperforms crowdsourced human supervision, significantly improving the training of models like Claude 3.5.
AI.conclusion: ICM can effectively elicit the superhuman capabilities of language models and improve their training, resulting in better performance than traditional methods.
key_contributions: Introduction of Internal Coherence Maximization (ICM) for unsupervised fine-tuning.
Demonstration of ICM's effectiveness on various benchmark tasks.
Training a reward model and assistant that outperform human-supervised versions.

title: (De)composing Craft: An Elementary Grammar for Sharing Expertise in Craft Workflows
summary:
Craft practices rely on evolving archives of skill and knowledge, developed
through generations of craftspeople experimenting with designs, materials, and
techniques. Better documentation of these practices enables the sharing of
knowledge and expertise between sites and generations. However, most
documentation focuses solely on the linear steps leading to final artifacts,
neglecting the tacit knowledge necessary to improvise, or adapt workflows to
meet the unique demands of each craft project. This omission limits knowledge
sharing and reduces craft to a mechanical endeavor, rather than a sophisticated
way of seeing, thinking, and doing. Drawing on expert interviews and literature
from HCI, CSCW and the social sciences, we develop an elementary grammar to
document improvisational actions of real-world craft practices. We demonstrate
the utility of this grammar with an interface called CraftLink that can be used
to analyze expert videos and semi-automatically generate documentation to
convey material and contextual variations of craft practices. Our user study
with expert crocheters (N=7) using this interface evaluates our grammar's
effectiveness in capturing and sharing expert knowledge with other
craftspeople, offering new pathways for computational systems to support
collaborative archives of knowledge and practice within communities.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a grammar for documenting improvisational craft practices, illustrated with the CraftLink interface, which aids in knowledge sharing among craftspeople.
AI.motivation: To improve the documentation of craft practices beyond linear steps by capturing the tacit knowledge necessary for improvisation and adaptation in crafts.
AI.method: The authors developed an elementary grammar for documenting improvisational actions, demonstrated via an interface called CraftLink that analyzes expert videos to generate documentation.
AI.result: User studies with expert crocheters using CraftLink showed that the grammar effectively captures and facilitates sharing of expert knowledge, enhancing collaborative craft practices.
AI.conclusion: The proposed grammar and CraftLink interface provide new ways for computational systems to support knowledge sharing in craft communities, preserving the sophistication of craft practices.
key_contributions: Development of a grammar for documenting improvisational craft actions
Creation of the CraftLink interface for semi-automated documentation generation
Evaluation of effectiveness through user studies with expert crocheters

title: When Large Language Models are Reliable for Judging Empathic Communication
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) excel at generating empathic responses in
text-based conversations. But, how reliably do they judge the nuances of
empathic communication? We investigate this question by comparing how experts,
crowdworkers, and LLMs annotate empathic communication across four evaluative
frameworks drawn from psychology, natural language processing, and
communications applied to 200 real-world conversations where one speaker shares
a personal problem and the other offers support. Drawing on 3,150 expert
annotations, 2,844 crowd annotations, and 3,150 LLM annotations, we assess
inter-rater reliability between these three annotator groups. We find that
expert agreement is high but varies across the frameworks' sub-components
depending on their clarity, complexity, and subjectivity. We show that expert
agreement offers a more informative benchmark for contextualizing LLM
performance than standard classification metrics. Across all four frameworks,
LLMs consistently approach this expert level benchmark and exceed the
reliability of crowdworkers. These results demonstrate how LLMs, when validated
on specific tasks with appropriate benchmarks, can support transparency and
oversight in emotionally sensitive applications including their use as
conversational companions.

AI.tldr: The study investigates the reliability of large language models (LLMs) in judging empathic communication compared to experts and crowdworkers.
AI.motivation: To understand how reliably LLMs can assess the nuances of empathic communication in text-based interactions, particularly in emotionally sensitive contexts.
AI.method: The research compares expert, crowdworker, and LLM annotations on empathic communication across four psychological and communication frameworks using data from 200 real-world conversations.
AI.result: LLMs show a high level of agreement with expert annotations, surpassing crowdworker reliability, and their performance varies by framework components' clarity and subjectivity.
AI.conclusion: LLMs can serve as valuable tools for ensuring transparency and oversight in emotionally sensitive applications, particularly when validated against expert benchmarks.
key_contributions: Assessment of LLM performance against expert benchmarks in empathic communication.
Demonstration of LLM reliability in comparison to crowdworker annotations.
Identification of framework components influencing expert agreement.
AI.limitations: The findings may vary across different contexts and types of conversations; further validation is needed.

title: The Role of Generative AI in Facilitating Social Interactions: A Scoping Review
comment:
Preprint version of a manuscript submitted to ACM Transactions on
  Computer-Human Interaction (TOCHI), under review. 39 pages, 4 figures
summary:
Reduced social connectedness increasingly poses a threat to mental health,
life expectancy, and general well-being. Generative AI (GAI) technologies, such
as large language models (LLMs) and image generation tools, are increasingly
integrated into applications aimed at enhancing human social experiences.
Despite their growing presence, little is known about how these technologies
influence social interactions. This scoping review investigates how GAI-based
applications are currently designed to facilitate social interaction, what
forms of social engagement they target, and which design and evaluation
methodologies designers use to create and evaluate them. Through an analysis of
30 studies published since 2020, we identify key trends in application domains
including storytelling, socio-emotional skills training, reminiscence,
collaborative learning, music making, and general conversation. We highlight
the role of participatory and co-design approaches in fostering both effective
technology use and social engagement, while also examining socio-ethical
concerns such as cultural bias and accessibility. This review underscores the
potential of GAI to support dynamic and personalized interactions, but calls
for greater attention to equitable design practices and inclusive evaluation
strategies.

AI.tldr: This scoping review examines the role of generative AI technologies in enhancing human social interaction, analyzing 30 studies to identify trends and methodologies in design and evaluation.
AI.motivation: To address the increasing concern of reduced social connectedness and its impact on mental health and well-being, exploring how generative AI can facilitate social interactions.
AI.method: Analysis of 30 studies published since 2020 focusing on GAI applications in various domains such as storytelling, training, and collaborative learning.
AI.result: Key trends in the applications are identified, including advancements in participatory design and socio-emotional skills development, alongside highlighting socio-ethical concerns.
AI.conclusion: GAI technologies have the potential to foster meaningful social interactions, but there is a need for equitable design and inclusive evaluation practices.
key_contributions: Identification of application domains where GAI enhances social interactions
Emphasis on participatory and co-design methodologies
Discussion of socio-ethical issues related to GAI applications
AI.limitations: Limited to studies published since 2020; focuses on existing research rather than empirical evaluation of the technologies themselves.

title: Analyzing Emotions in Bangla Social Media Comments Using Machine Learning and LIME
summary:
Research on understanding emotions in written language continues to expand,
especially for understudied languages with distinctive regional expressions and
cultural features, such as Bangla. This study examines emotion analysis using
22,698 social media comments from the EmoNoBa dataset. For language analysis,
we employ machine learning models: Linear SVM, KNN, and Random Forest with
n-gram data from a TF-IDF vectorizer. We additionally investigated how PCA
affects the reduction of dimensionality. Moreover, we utilized a BiLSTM model
and AdaBoost to improve decision trees. To make our machine learning models
easier to understand, we used LIME to explain the predictions of the AdaBoost
classifier, which uses decision trees. With the goal of advancing sentiment
analysis in languages with limited resources, our work examines various
techniques to find efficient techniques for emotion identification in Bangla.

AI.tldr: This study analyzes emotions in Bangla using 22,698 social media comments and various machine learning models including SVM, KNN, Random Forest, BiLSTM, and AdaBoost, while employing dimensionality reduction and interpretability techniques.
AI.motivation: The research aims to enhance emotion analysis in less-studied languages, particularly Bangla, which features unique regional expressions and cultural aspects.
AI.method: The study uses machine learning models such as Linear SVM, KNN, Random Forest, BiLSTM, and AdaBoost for emotion analysis, employing TF-IDF vectors and dimensionality reduction techniques like PCA. LIME is used to explain the predictions of the AdaBoost classifier.
AI.result: The various techniques investigated showed potential for effective emotion identification in Bangla, contributing to sentiment analysis in languages with limited resources.
AI.conclusion: The research provides insights into improving emotion analysis in Bangla through advanced machine learning techniques, demonstrating the applicability of these methods in resource-constrained settings.
key_contributions: Application of machine learning models to the EmoNoBa dataset
Utilization of LIME for model interpretability
Exploration of PCA for dimensionality reduction in language analysis
AI.limitations: The focus is primarily on Bangla, which may limit generalizability to other languages with different linguistic structures.

title: Video-Mediated Emotion Disclosure: A Study of Mental Health Vlogging by People with Schizophrenia on YouTube
summary:
Individuals with schizophrenia frequently experience intense emotions and
often turn to vlogging as a medium for emotional expression. While previous
research has predominantly focused on text based disclosure, little is known
about how individuals construct narratives around emotions and emotional
experiences in video blogs. Our study addresses this gap by analyzing 200
YouTube videos created by individuals with schizophrenia. Drawing on media
research and self presentation theories, we developed a visual analysis
framework to disentangle these videos. Our analysis revealed diverse practices
of emotion disclosure through both verbal and visual channels, highlighting the
dynamic interplay between these modes of expression. We found that the
deliberate construction of visual elements, including environmental settings
and specific aesthetic choices, appears to foster more supportive and engaged
viewer responses. These findings underscore the need for future large scale
quantitative research examining how visual features shape video mediated
communication on social media platforms. Such investigations would inform the
development of care centered video sharing platforms that better support
individuals managing illness experiences.

AI.tldr: This study analyzes how individuals with schizophrenia express emotions in vlogs, uncovering the interplay of verbal and visual communication in their narratives.
AI.motivation: To fill the gap in understanding emotional expression through video blogs among individuals with schizophrenia, particularly focusing on narrative construction.
AI.method: Analyzed 200 YouTube videos of individuals with schizophrenia using a visual analysis framework derived from media research and self-presentation theories.
AI.result: The analysis revealed diverse practices of emotion disclosure, showing how visual elements and aesthetics can enhance viewer engagement and support.
AI.conclusion: Future research should explore how video features influence communication on social media, which could help develop better platforms for those managing illness experiences.
key_contributions: Developed a visual analysis framework for studying emotional narratives in vlogs.
Highlighted the significance of visual and aesthetic choices in emotional expression.
Called for large-scale quantitative studies on video-mediated communication.
AI.limitations: The study is qualitative and does not provide quantitative measurements or generalizable data.

title: Measuring Corporate Human Capital Disclosures: Lexicon, Data, Code, and Research Opportunities
summary:
Human capital (HC) is increasingly important to corporate value creation.
Unlike other assets, however, HC is not currently subject to well-defined
measurement or disclosure rules. We use a machine learning algorithm (word2vec)
trained on a confirmed set of HC disclosures to develop a comprehensive list of
HC-related keywords classified into five subcategories (DEI; health and safety;
labor relations and culture; compensation and benefits; and demographics and
other) that capture the multidimensional nature of HC management. We share our
lexicon, corporate HC disclosures, and the Python code used to develop the
lexicon, and we provide detailed examples of using our data and code, including
for fine-tuning a BERT model. Researchers can use our HC lexicon (or modify the
code to capture another construct of interest) with their samples of corporate
communications to address pertinent HC questions. We close with a discussion of
future research opportunities related to HC management and disclosure.

AI.tldr: This paper develops a machine learning-based lexicon for Human Capital (HC) disclosures, suggests methods for addressing HC-related questions in corporate communications, and outlines future research opportunities.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of defined measurement or disclosure rules for Human Capital as a corporate asset.
AI.method: A machine learning algorithm (word2vec) is employed to create a comprehensive lexicon of HC-related keywords classified into five subcategories.
AI.result: The study produces a lexicon of HC keywords, a dataset of corporate HC disclosures, and Python code for utilizing this lexicon, including examples for BERT model fine-tuning.
AI.conclusion: The lexicon and associated resources promote further research and exploration of Human Capital management and disclosure in corporate settings.
key_contributions: Development of a comprehensive HC keyword lexicon
Sharing of Python code for lexicon development
Examples for adapting the lexicon for various corporate communication analyses

title: Instance-Based Transfer Learning with Similarity-Aware Subject Selection for Cross-Subject SSVEP-Based BCIs
comment: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
summary:
Steady-state visual evoked potential (SSVEP)-based brain-computer interfaces
(BCIs) can achieve high recognition accuracy with sufficient training data.
Transfer learning presents a promising solution to alleviate data requirements
for the target subject by leveraging data from source subjects; however,
effectively addressing individual variability among both target and source
subjects remains a challenge. This paper proposes a novel transfer learning
framework, termed instance-based task-related component analysis (iTRCA), which
leverages knowledge from source subjects while considering their individual
contributions. iTRCA extracts two types of features: (1) the subject-general
feature, capturing shared information between source and target subjects in a
common latent space, and (2) the subject-specific feature, preserving the
unique characteristics of the target subject. To mitigate negative transfer, we
further design an enhanced framework, subject selection-based iTRCA (SS-iTRCA),
which integrates a similarity-based subject selection strategy to identify
appropriate source subjects for transfer based on their task-related components
(TRCs). Comparative evaluations on the Benchmark, BETA, and a self-collected
dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed iTRCA and SS-iTRCA
frameworks. This study provides a potential solution for developing
high-performance SSVEP-based BCIs with reduced target subject data.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a novel transfer learning framework for SSVEP-based brain-computer interfaces that addresses individual variability in subjects' performance by utilizing both general and subject-specific features and includes a subject selection strategy.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to improve the accuracy of SSVEP-based BCIs while reducing the need for extensive training data specific to the target subject by leveraging data from other subjects.
AI.method: The framework, termed instance-based task-related component analysis (iTRCA), extracts both subject-general and subject-specific features, and includes a method for selecting appropriate source subjects to mitigate negative transfer effects.
AI.result: Comparative evaluations on multiple datasets show that the proposed iTRCA and subject selection-based iTRCA (SS-iTRCA) frameworks significantly enhance performance, demonstrating their effectiveness in improving SSVEP-based BCI outcomes.
AI.conclusion: The study suggests that the iTRCA framework can lead to high-performance SSVEP-based BCIs with less required data from the target subject, potentially broadening the application of BCIs for non-expert users.
key_contributions: Introduction of instance-based task-related component analysis (iTRCA) framework for BCIs
Development of subject selection-based iTRCA (SS-iTRCA) to enhance transfer learning
Effective feature extraction addressing individual subject variability
AI.limitations: The study may need further validation across diverse populations and additional tasks to ensure generalizability of the results.

title: Can LLMs Generate Good Stories? Insights and Challenges from a Narrative Planning Perspective
summary:
Story generation has been a prominent application of Large Language Models
(LLMs). However, understanding LLMs' ability to produce high-quality stories
remains limited due to challenges in automatic evaluation methods and the high
cost and subjectivity of manual evaluation. Computational narratology offers
valuable insights into what constitutes a good story, which has been applied in
the symbolic narrative planning approach to story generation. This work aims to
deepen the understanding of LLMs' story generation capabilities by using them
to solve narrative planning problems. We present a benchmark for evaluating
LLMs on narrative planning based on literature examples, focusing on causal
soundness, character intentionality, and dramatic conflict. Our experiments
show that GPT-4 tier LLMs can generate causally sound stories at small scales,
but planning with character intentionality and dramatic conflict remains
challenging, requiring LLMs trained with reinforcement learning for complex
reasoning. The results offer insights on the scale of stories that LLMs can
generate while maintaining quality from different aspects. Our findings also
highlight interesting problem solving behaviors and shed lights on challenges
and considerations for applying LLM narrative planning in game environments.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates LLMs' story generation abilities through a benchmark focused on narrative planning, revealing strengths and challenges in generating quality stories.
AI.motivation: The study aims to enhance understanding of LLMs' story generation capabilities by addressing challenges in evaluation methods and combining insights from computational narratology.
AI.method: A benchmark for evaluating LLMs on narrative planning was created, focusing on aspects such as causal soundness, character intentionality, and dramatic conflict, using literature examples for assessment.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrated that GPT-4 tier LLMs can produce causally sound stories on a small scale, but struggle with incorporating character intentionality and dramatic conflict, indicating a need for reinforcement learning in complex reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: The findings offer insights into the scale of stories LLMs can generate while maintaining quality, highlighting both problem-solving behaviors and challenges in LLM narrative planning applications, particularly in gaming contexts.
key_contributions: Benchmark for evaluating LLMs in narrative planning.
Insights into LLM story generation capabilities and limitations.
Identification of challenges in producing quality narratives with LLMs.
AI.limitations: The study primarily focuses on small-scale story generation, which may not fully represent the capabilities of LLMs on larger narratives.

title: Q2E: Query-to-Event Decomposition for Zero-Shot Multilingual Text-to-Video Retrieval
summary:
Recent approaches have shown impressive proficiency in extracting and
leveraging parametric knowledge from Large-Language Models (LLMs) and
Vision-Language Models (VLMs). In this work, we consider how we can improve the
identification and retrieval of videos related to complex real-world events by
automatically extracting latent parametric knowledge about those events. We
present Q2E: a Query-to-Event decomposition method for zero-shot multilingual
text-to-video retrieval, adaptable across datasets, domains, LLMs, or VLMs. Our
approach demonstrates that we can enhance the understanding of otherwise overly
simplified human queries by decomposing the query using the knowledge embedded
in LLMs and VLMs. We additionally show how to apply our approach to both visual
and speech-based inputs. To combine this varied multimodal knowledge, we adopt
entropy-based fusion scoring for zero-shot fusion. Through evaluations on two
diverse datasets and multiple retrieval metrics, we demonstrate that Q2E
outperforms several state-of-the-art baselines. Our evaluation also shows that
integrating audio information can significantly improve text-to-video
retrieval. We have released code and data for future research.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Q2E, a multilingual text-to-video retrieval method that enhances query understanding through decomposition by leveraging knowledge from LLMs and VLMs, showing improved performance over existing baselines.
AI.motivation: To improve the identification and retrieval of videos related to complex real-world events by extracting latent parametric knowledge.
AI.method: Q2E: a Query-to-Event decomposition method adaptable across datasets and domains, using entropy-based fusion for zero-shot fusion of multimodal inputs.
AI.result: Q2E outperforms several state-of-the-art baselines on two diverse datasets, showing significant improvement in text-to-video retrieval when integrating audio information.
AI.conclusion: The approach enhances the understanding of human queries and demonstrates the effectiveness of combining visual and auditory data for video retrieval.
key_contributions: Introduction of Q2E for multilingual text-to-video retrieval
Effective application of entropy-based fusion for multimodal inputs
Demonstrated improvements in retrieval performance with audio integration

title: TTT-Bench: A Benchmark for Evaluating Reasoning Ability with Simple and Novel Tic-Tac-Toe-style Games
summary:
Large reasoning models (LRMs) have demonstrated impressive reasoning
capabilities across a broad range of tasks including Olympiad-level
mathematical problems, indicating evidence of their complex reasoning
abilities. While many reasoning benchmarks focus on the STEM domain, the
ability of LRMs to reason correctly in broader task domains remains
underexplored. In this work, we introduce \textbf{TTT-Bench}, a new benchmark
that is designed to evaluate basic strategic, spatial, and logical reasoning
abilities in LRMs through a suite of four two-player Tic-Tac-Toe-style games
that humans can effortlessly solve from a young age. We propose a simple yet
scalable programmatic approach for generating verifiable two-player game
problems for TTT-Bench. Although these games are trivial for humans, they
require reasoning about the intentions of the opponent, as well as the game
board's spatial configurations, to ensure a win. We evaluate a diverse set of
state-of-the-art LRMs, and \textbf{discover that the models that excel at hard
math problems frequently fail at these simple reasoning games}. Further testing
reveals that our evaluated reasoning models score on average $\downarrow$ 41\%
\& $\downarrow$ 5\% lower on TTT-Bench compared to MATH 500 \& AIME 2024
respectively, with larger models achieving higher performance using shorter
reasoning traces, where most of the models struggle on long-term strategic
reasoning situations on simple and new TTT-Bench tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces TTT-Bench, a benchmark to evaluate large reasoning models' strategic, spatial, and logical reasoning abilities through simple two-player games.
AI.motivation: To address the limited exploration of large reasoning models' capabilities in broader task domains beyond STEM, particularly in simple strategic games.
AI.method: Introduction of TTT-Bench, involving a programmatic approach to generate two-player Tic-Tac-Toe-style game problems for evaluating reasoning in LRMs.
AI.result: State-of-the-art LRMs that excel in mathematical reasoning often struggle with the TTT-Bench games, showing a marked decrease in performance compared to established math benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest a disparity in reasoning capabilities between complex math problems and simple strategic games, highlighting an area for further investigation.
key_contributions: Introduction of a new benchmark (TTT-Bench) for reasoning models
Showcasing the discrepancy in performance between math and reasoning tasks
Proposing a scalable method for generating verifiable game problems
AI.limitations: The focus is on a narrow set of reasoning games and might not represent all reasoning abilities of LRMs.

title: When Large Language Models are Reliable for Judging Empathic Communication
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) excel at generating empathic responses in
text-based conversations. But, how reliably do they judge the nuances of
empathic communication? We investigate this question by comparing how experts,
crowdworkers, and LLMs annotate empathic communication across four evaluative
frameworks drawn from psychology, natural language processing, and
communications applied to 200 real-world conversations where one speaker shares
a personal problem and the other offers support. Drawing on 3,150 expert
annotations, 2,844 crowd annotations, and 3,150 LLM annotations, we assess
inter-rater reliability between these three annotator groups. We find that
expert agreement is high but varies across the frameworks' sub-components
depending on their clarity, complexity, and subjectivity. We show that expert
agreement offers a more informative benchmark for contextualizing LLM
performance than standard classification metrics. Across all four frameworks,
LLMs consistently approach this expert level benchmark and exceed the
reliability of crowdworkers. These results demonstrate how LLMs, when validated
on specific tasks with appropriate benchmarks, can support transparency and
oversight in emotionally sensitive applications including their use as
conversational companions.

AI.tldr: This paper examines how well large language models (LLMs) assess empathic communication by comparing their performance with experts and crowdworkers across various frameworks.
AI.motivation: To investigate the reliability of LLMs in judging nuances of empathic communication in text-based conversations.
AI.method: The study compares annotations of empathic communication made by experts, crowdworkers, and LLMs across four evaluative frameworks, using real-world conversations.
AI.result: Expert agreement is high but varies based on the framework's characteristics; LLMs approach expert benchmarks and exceed crowdworker reliability.
AI.conclusion: LLMs validated on specific tasks can enhance transparency and oversight in emotionally sensitive applications.
key_contributions: Demonstration of high expert agreement across different frameworks.
Comparison of LLM performance against experts and crowd annotations.
LLMs shown to exceed reliability of crowdworkers in assessing empathic communication.

title: Classifying Unreliable Narrators with Large Language Models
summary:
Often when we interact with a first-person account of events, we consider
whether or not the narrator, the primary speaker of the text, is reliable. In
this paper, we propose using computational methods to identify unreliable
narrators, i.e. those who unintentionally misrepresent information. Borrowing
literary theory from narratology to define different types of unreliable
narrators based on a variety of textual phenomena, we present TUNa, a
human-annotated dataset of narratives from multiple domains, including blog
posts, subreddit posts, hotel reviews, and works of literature. We define
classification tasks for intra-narrational, inter-narrational, and
inter-textual unreliabilities and analyze the performance of popular
open-weight and proprietary LLMs for each. We propose learning from literature
to perform unreliable narrator classification on real-world text data. To this
end, we experiment with few-shot, fine-tuning, and curriculum learning
settings. Our results show that this task is very challenging, and there is
potential for using LLMs to identify unreliable narrators. We release our
expert-annotated dataset and code and invite future research in this area.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes computational methods for identifying unreliable narrators in narrative texts, introducing the TUNa dataset and evaluating LLMs for this task.
AI.motivation: To explore and identify unreliable narrators in various narrative texts through computational methods, borrowing from narratology.
AI.method: The paper presents a human-annotated dataset of narratives and defines classification tasks to analyze different types of unreliabilities, experimenting with techniques like few-shot learning and fine-tuning on LLMs.
AI.result: The evaluation shows significant challenges in identifying unreliable narrators, indicating the potential utility of LLMs in this area.
AI.conclusion: The authors release their dataset and code, encouraging further research into unreliable narrator classification with LLMs.
key_contributions: Introduction of TUNa, a dataset for unreliable narrator classification.
Framework for classifying types of unreliabilities in narratives.
Exploration of LLMs for unreliable narrator identification across various domains.
AI.limitations: The task of identifying unreliable narrators is shown to be challenging, indicating areas for improvement in LLM capabilities.

title: ToxSyn-PT: A Large-Scale Synthetic Dataset for Hate Speech Detection in Portuguese
summary:
We present ToxSyn-PT, the first large-scale Portuguese corpus that enables
fine-grained hate-speech classification across nine legally protected minority
groups. The dataset contains 53,274 synthetic sentences equally distributed
between minorities groups and toxicity labels. ToxSyn-PT is created through a
novel four-stage pipeline: (1) a compact, manually curated seed; (2) few-shot
expansion with an instruction-tuned LLM; (3) paraphrase-based augmentation; and
(4) enrichment, plus additional neutral texts to curb overfitting to
group-specific cues. The resulting corpus is class-balanced, stylistically
diverse, and free from the social-media domain that dominate existing
Portuguese datasets. Despite domain differences with traditional benchmarks,
experiments on both binary and multi-label classification on the corpus yields
strong results across five public Portuguese hate-speech datasets,
demonstrating robust generalization even across domain boundaries. The dataset
is publicly released to advance research on synthetic data and hate-speech
detection in low-resource settings.

AI.tldr: ToxSyn-PT is the first large-scale Portuguese corpus for hate-speech classification across minority groups, using a novel four-stage creation pipeline.
AI.motivation: To provide a high-quality synthetic dataset for hate-speech detection tailored to Portuguese and address the lack of such resources in low-resource settings.
AI.method: The dataset was created using a four-stage pipeline: starting with a curated seed, expanding using an LLM, augmenting via paraphrases, and enriching with additional neutral texts.
AI.result: Strong classification results were achieved in experiments on both binary and multi-label tasks across five public Portuguese hate-speech datasets, demonstrating good generalization capabilities.
AI.conclusion: ToxSyn-PT offers a valuable resource for advancing research in synthetic data and hate-speech detection, particularly in Portuguese and other low-resource contexts.
key_contributions: Introduction of ToxSyn-PT corpus for Portuguese hate-speech analysis.
Methodological advancements in dataset generation using LLMs and paraphrasing techniques.
Public release of a balanced and diverse dataset for further research.
AI.limitations: The dataset may not cover all aspects of hate speech and may require further validation against real-world data.

title: Do Language Models Have Bayesian Brains? Distinguishing Stochastic and Deterministic Decision Patterns within Large Language Models
summary:
Language models are essentially probability distributions over token
sequences. Auto-regressive models generate sentences by iteratively computing
and sampling from the distribution of the next token. This iterative sampling
introduces stochasticity, leading to the assumption that language models make
probabilistic decisions, similar to sampling from unknown distributions.
Building on this assumption, prior research has used simulated Gibbs sampling,
inspired by experiments designed to elicit human priors, to infer the priors of
language models. In this paper, we revisit a critical question: Do language
models possess Bayesian brains? Our findings show that under certain
conditions, language models can exhibit near-deterministic decision-making,
such as producing maximum likelihood estimations, even with a non-zero sampling
temperature. This challenges the sampling assumption and undermines previous
methods for eliciting human-like priors. Furthermore, we demonstrate that
without proper scrutiny, a system with deterministic behavior undergoing
simulated Gibbs sampling can converge to a "false prior." To address this, we
propose a straightforward approach to distinguish between stochastic and
deterministic decision patterns in Gibbs sampling, helping to prevent the
inference of misleading language model priors. We experiment on a variety of
large language models to identify their decision patterns under various
circumstances. Our results provide key insights in understanding decision
making of large language models.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates whether language models exhibit Bayesian decision-making, revealing that they can show deterministic behavior under certain conditions, which challenges previous assumptions about their probabilistic nature.
AI.motivation: The study aims to explore the decision-making processes of language models and whether they align with Bayesian principles.
AI.method: The authors re-evaluate the assumption of stochasticity in language models' decision-making through simulated Gibbs sampling and conduct experiments with various large language models to analyze their decision patterns.
AI.result: Findings indicate that language models can behave deterministically, producing maximum likelihood estimations even with a non-zero sampling temperature, and highlight the risks of inferring misleading priors in their decision-making processes.
AI.conclusion: The research raises critical questions about the assumed probabilistic nature of language models and suggests methods to distinguish between stochastic and deterministic decisions, enhancing our understanding of their behavior.
key_contributions: Reevaluation of decision-making in language models with a focus on Bayesian principles
Introduction of a method to differentiate between stochastic and deterministic decision patterns in Gibbs sampling
Experimental insights on decision-making behaviors across various large language models

title: ClusterUCB: Efficient Gradient-Based Data Selection for Targeted Fine-Tuning of LLMs
summary:
Gradient-based data influence approximation has been leveraged to select
useful data samples in the supervised fine-tuning of large language models.
However, the computation of gradients throughout the fine-tuning process
requires too many resources to be feasible in practice. In this paper, we
propose an efficient gradient-based data selection framework with clustering
and a modified Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) algorithm. Based on the intuition
that data samples with similar gradient features will have similar influences,
we first perform clustering on the training data pool. Then, we frame the
inter-cluster data selection as a constrained computing budget allocation
problem and consider it a multi-armed bandit problem. A modified UCB algorithm
is leveraged to solve this problem. Specifically, during the iterative sampling
process, historical data influence information is recorded to directly estimate
the distributions of each cluster, and a cold start is adopted to balance
exploration and exploitation. Experimental results on various benchmarks show
that our proposed framework, ClusterUCB, can achieve comparable results to the
original gradient-based data selection methods while greatly reducing computing
consumption.

AI.tldr: This paper presents ClusterUCB, an efficient framework for data selection in the fine-tuning of large language models, using clustering and a modified Upper Confidence Bound algorithm to reduce computational overhead while maintaining performance.
AI.motivation: The need for efficient data selection in supervised fine-tuning of large language models due to the high resource requirements of traditional gradient-based methods.
AI.method: Cluster the training data based on gradient features, then formulate the data selection as a constrained budget allocation problem addressed through a multi-armed bandit approach with a modified UCB algorithm.
