AI.result: Experiments with four language models and five multi-hop multiple-choice question answering datasets show that FUR can effectively change model predictions by unlearning certain reasoning steps, indicating a correlation between CoT and model faithfulness.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest that CoTs may not always reflect the models' internal beliefs, and alterations in reasoning can lead to different answers, indicating complexities in model reasoning.
key_contributions: Introduction of the FUR framework for evaluating CoT faithfulness
Demonstration of FUR's effectiveness across multiple language models and datasets
Insights into the impact of reasoning unlearning on model predictions
AI.limitations: The framework may require further validation across a broader range of models and tasks to establish generalizability.

title: Obliviate: Efficient Unmemorization for Protecting Intellectual Property in Large Language Models
summary:
Recent copyright agreements between AI companies and content creators
underscore the need for fine-grained control over language models' ability to
reproduce copyrighted text. Existing defenses-ranging from aggressive
unlearning to simplistic output filters-either sacrifice model utility or
inadequately address verbatim leakage. We introduce Obliviate, a lightweight
post-training method that surgically suppresses exact reproduction of specified
sequences while preserving semantic understanding. Obliviate first identifies
memorized passages and then, for each target token, minimally adjusts the
model's output distribution via a Kullback-Leibler divergence penalty to drive
down the probability of exact reproduction. Simultaneously, we enforce a
consistency loss on non-target tokens to retain the model's fluency and task
performance. We evaluate Obliviate on four popular 6-8B-parameter models
(LLaMA-3.1, LLaMA-3.1-Instruct, Qwen-2.5, and Yi-1.5) using synthetic
memorization benchmarks and organic copyrighted excerpts (e.g., Moby Dick,
Frankenstein, Alice in Wonderland and Les Miserables). Across all settings,
Obliviate reduces verbatim recall by two orders of magnitude (e.g., from
hundreds of words to fewer than 12) while degrading downstream accuracy by at
most 1% on HellaSwag, MMLU, TruthfulQA, and Winogrande. Furthermore, we
benchmark Obliviate aganist different unlearning and copyright techniques using
the MUSE and CoTaEval benchmarks. These results position Obliviate as a
practical, high-fidelity solution for copyright compliance in deployed LLMs.

AI.tldr: Obliviate is a method that reduces copyright infringement in language models by suppressing exact reproductions of specified sequences while maintaining model fluency and performance.
AI.motivation: The need for fine-grained control over language models to prevent copyright infringement due to the reproduction of copyrighted text.
AI.method: Obliviate identifies memorized passages and uses a Kullback-Leibler divergence penalty to suppress exact token reproduction, while enforcing consistency loss on non-target tokens.
AI.result: Obliviate reduces verbatim recall by two orders of magnitude across various models, with minimal impact on overall task performance (at most 1% degradation).
AI.conclusion: Obliviate is a practical and effective solution for ensuring copyright compliance in language models without significantly affecting their performance.
key_contributions: Introduced a lightweight method for suppressing verbatim text reproduction in LLMs.
Demonstrated significant reduction in copyright infringement while maintaining accuracy.
Evaluated across multiple popular language models and benchmarks.

title: Mind the Style Gap: Meta-Evaluation of Style and Attribute Transfer Metrics
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) make it easy to rewrite a text in any style --
e.g. to make it more polite, persuasive, or more positive -- but evaluation
thereof is not straightforward. A challenge lies in measuring content
preservation: that content not attributable to style change is retained. This
paper presents a large meta-evaluation of metrics for evaluating style and
attribute transfer, focusing on content preservation. We find that
meta-evaluation studies on existing datasets lead to misleading conclusions
about the suitability of metrics for content preservation. Widely used metrics
show a high correlation with human judgments despite being deemed unsuitable
for the task -- because they do not abstract from style changes when evaluating
content preservation. We show that the overly high correlations with human
judgment stem from the nature of the test data. To address this issue, we
introduce a new, challenging test set specifically designed for evaluating
content preservation metrics for style transfer. Using this dataset, we
demonstrate that suitable metrics for content preservation for style transfer
indeed are style-aware. To support efficient evaluation, we propose a new
style-aware method that utilises small language models, obtaining a higher
alignment with human judgements than prompting a model of a similar size as an
autorater.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates metrics for style transfer in LLMs, emphasizing content preservation and introduces a new dataset for better assessment.
AI.motivation: The need for effective evaluation methods for content preservation in style transfer using Large Language Models (LLMs).
AI.method: A large meta-evaluation of existing metrics for style and attribute transfer was conducted, leading to the creation of a new, challenging test set designed to assess these metrics.
AI.result: The study reveals that common metrics, while showing high correlation with human judgments, do not effectively measure content preservation due to their inability to abstract from style changes.
AI.conclusion: The authors propose a style-aware evaluation method and a new test set that provides better alignment with human judgments for content preservation metrics in style transfer.
key_contributions: Introduction of a new test set for content preservation evaluation in style transfer.
Demonstration that suitable metrics for content preservation are style-aware.
Proposal of a new style-aware method using small language models for evaluation.
AI.limitations: Existing metrics are misleading for judging content preservation; the results are limited to the datasets used in the study.

title: The Esethu Framework: Reimagining Sustainable Dataset Governance and Curation for Low-Resource Languages
summary:
This paper presents the Esethu Framework, a sustainable data curation
framework specifically designed to empower local communities and ensure
equitable benefit-sharing from their linguistic resource. This framework is
supported by the Esethu license, a novel community-centric data license. As a
proof of concept, we introduce the Vuk'uzenzele isiXhosa Speech Dataset
(ViXSD), an open-source corpus developed under the Esethu Framework and
License. The dataset, containing read speech from native isiXhosa speakers
enriched with demographic and linguistic metadata, demonstrates how
community-driven licensing and curation principles can bridge resource gaps in
automatic speech recognition (ASR) for African languages while safeguarding the
interests of data creators. We describe the framework guiding dataset
development, outline the Esethu license provisions, present the methodology for
ViXSD, and present ASR experiments validating ViXSD's usability in building and
refining voice-driven applications for isiXhosa.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the Esethu Framework for data curation to empower local communities and presents the Vuk'uzenzele isiXhosa Speech Dataset (ViXSD) as a proof of concept under this framework.
AI.motivation: To empower local communities and ensure equitable benefit-sharing from linguistic resources through sustainable data curation.
AI.method: The Esethu Framework, supported by the Esethu license, guides the development of community-centric datasets, exemplified by the ViXSD, which includes rich metadata.
AI.result: The ViXSD demonstrates how community-driven principles can enhance automatic speech recognition (ASR) for African languages, providing valuable data for building voice-driven applications.
AI.conclusion: The Esethu Framework and ViXSD can bridge resource gaps in ASR for African languages while protecting the interests of data creators.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Esethu Framework for sustainable data curation
Development of the Vuk'uzenzele isiXhosa Speech Dataset (ViXSD)
Novel community-centric Esethu license for data sharing

title: Large Language Models for Multilingual Previously Fact-Checked Claim Detection
summary:
In our era of widespread false information, human fact-checkers often face
the challenge of duplicating efforts when verifying claims that may have
already been addressed in other countries or languages. As false information
transcends linguistic boundaries, the ability to automatically detect
previously fact-checked claims across languages has become an increasingly
important task. This paper presents the first comprehensive evaluation of large
language models (LLMs) for multilingual previously fact-checked claim
detection. We assess seven LLMs across 20 languages in both monolingual and
cross-lingual settings. Our results show that while LLMs perform well for
high-resource languages, they struggle with low-resource languages. Moreover,
translating original texts into English proved to be beneficial for
low-resource languages. These findings highlight the potential of LLMs for
multilingual previously fact-checked claim detection and provide a foundation
for further research on this promising application of LLMs.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates large language models for multilingual detection of previously fact-checked claims, revealing performance disparities between high-resource and low-resource languages.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of verifying claims that have already been fact-checked in different languages, thereby reducing duplicated efforts by human fact-checkers in the face of false information.
AI.method: The study evaluates seven large language models across 20 languages in both monolingual and cross-lingual settings to assess their effectiveness in detecting previously fact-checked claims.
AI.result: The results indicate strong performance for LLMs on high-resource languages, but a significant struggle with low-resource languages. Translating texts into English was found to be beneficial for detection in low-resource scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest that LLMs hold potential for improving multilingual fact-checking processes and provide a basis for further research in this area.
key_contributions: First comprehensive evaluation of LLMs for multilingual fact-checking detection
In-depth analysis across 20 languages
Findings highlight benefits of translation for low-resource languages
AI.limitations: The performance of LLMs is notably weaker in low-resource languages, indicating a need for further advancements in this area.

title: Improving LLM Safety Alignment with Dual-Objective Optimization
summary:
Existing training-time safety alignment techniques for large language models
(LLMs) remain vulnerable to jailbreak attacks. Direct preference optimization
(DPO), a widely deployed alignment method, exhibits limitations in both
experimental and theoretical contexts as its loss function proves suboptimal
for refusal learning. Through gradient-based analysis, we identify these
shortcomings and propose an improved safety alignment that disentangles DPO
objectives into two components: (1) robust refusal training, which encourages
refusal even when partial unsafe generations are produced, and (2) targeted
unlearning of harmful knowledge. This approach significantly increases LLM
robustness against a wide range of jailbreak attacks, including prefilling,
suffix, and multi-turn attacks across both in-distribution and
out-of-distribution scenarios. Furthermore, we introduce a method to emphasize
critical refusal tokens by incorporating a reward-based token-level weighting
mechanism for refusal learning, which further improves the robustness against
adversarial exploits. Our research also suggests that robustness to jailbreak
attacks is correlated with token distribution shifts in the training process
and internal representations of refusal and harmful tokens, offering valuable
directions for future research in LLM safety alignment. The code is available
at https://github.com/wicai24/DOOR-Alignment

AI.tldr: This paper addresses the vulnerabilities of large language models (LLMs) to jailbreak attacks and proposes an enhanced safety alignment technique to improve robustness.
AI.motivation: Current training-time safety alignment techniques for LLMs are inadequate against jailbreak attacks, and existing methods like direct preference optimization (DPO) show limitations.
AI.method: The authors use gradient-based analysis to propose an improved safety alignment that separates DPO objectives into robust refusal training and targeted unlearning of harmful knowledge.
AI.result: The proposed method significantly enhances LLM robustness against various jailbreak attacks, including prefilling and multi-turn attacks, in both in-distribution and out-of-distribution contexts.
AI.conclusion: The findings indicate a correlation between robustness to jailbreak attacks and shifts in token distributions during training, providing insights for future research in LLM safety alignment.
key_contributions: Introduction of robust refusal training for LLMs
Proposed targeted unlearning of harmful knowledge
Token-level weighting mechanism to enhance refusal learning

title: Social Bias Benchmark for Generation: A Comparison of Generation and QA-Based Evaluations
summary:
Measuring social bias in large language models (LLMs) is crucial, but
existing bias evaluation methods struggle to assess bias in long-form
generation. We propose a Bias Benchmark for Generation (BBG), an adaptation of
the Bias Benchmark for QA (BBQ), designed to evaluate social bias in long-form
generation by having LLMs generate continuations of story prompts. Building our
benchmark in English and Korean, we measure the probability of neutral and
biased generations across ten LLMs. We also compare our long-form story
generation evaluation results with multiple-choice BBQ evaluation, showing that
the two approaches produce inconsistent results.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a Benchmark for Measuring Bias in Long-form Generations by Large Language Models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: There is a pressing need to evaluate social bias in LLMs, especially in long-form text generation, as current methods are inadequate.
AI.method: The authors created the Bias Benchmark for Generation (BBG) that evaluates LLM outputs based on story prompt continuations in both English and Korean, measuring the instances of neutral versus biased content.
AI.result: The study reveals varying probabilities of neutral and biased generations across ten different LLMs and highlights inconsistencies between the long-form generation evaluations and the multiple-choice evaluations from the existing BBQ framework.
AI.conclusion: BBG provides a new framework for assessing bias in long-form generations that could inform better understanding and mitigation of social biases in AI-generated content.
key_contributions: Development of the Bias Benchmark for Generation (BBG) tailored for story prompts.
Cross-linguistic evaluation of bias in English and Korean.
Comparison of results from long-form and multiple-choice evaluation methods demonstrating their inconsistencies.
AI.limitations: The benchmark is still in the early stages and may require further refinement and validation across different contexts.

title: Computation Mechanism Behind LLM Position Generalization
summary:
Most written natural languages are composed of sequences of words and
sentences. Similar to humans, large language models (LLMs) exhibit flexibility
in handling textual positions - a phenomenon we term position generalization.
They can understand texts with position perturbations and generalize to longer
texts than those encountered during training with the latest techniques. These
phenomena suggest that LLMs handle positions tolerantly, but how LLMs
computationally process positional relevance remains largely unexplored. This
work connects the linguistic phenomenon with LLMs' computational mechanisms. We
show how LLMs enforce certain computational mechanisms for the aforementioned
tolerance in position perturbations. Despite the complex design of the
self-attention mechanism, this work reveals that LLMs learn a counterintuitive
disentanglement of attention logits. Their values show a 0.959 linear
correlation with an approximation of the arithmetic sum of positional relevance
and semantic importance. Furthermore, we identify a prevalent pattern in
intermediate features, which we prove theoretically enables this effect. The
pattern, which is different from how randomly initialized parameters would
behave, suggests that it is a learned behavior rather than a natural result of
the model architecture. Based on these findings, we provide computational
explanations and criteria for LLMs' position flexibilities. This work takes a
pioneering step in linking position generalization with modern LLMs' internal
mechanisms.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates how large language models (LLMs) exhibit tolerance in handling positional information in text, revealing that this flexibility is tied to their internal computational mechanisms.
AI.motivation: To understand how LLMs manage positional relevance and its computational processing, which has been largely overlooked in current research.
AI.method: The authors analyze the behavior of attention logits in LLMs and establish a connection between positional relevance and semantic importance through a linear correlation.
AI.result: They find a 0.959 linear correlation between attention logits and a combination of positional relevance and semantic importance, indicating a learned behavior rather than a consequence of architecture design.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a framework for explaining the position generalization seen in LLMs, demonstrating it relates to internal mechanisms rather than just architectural features.
key_contributions: Investigates positional relevance in LLMs
Establishes a correlation between attention logits and semantic importance
Proposes a theoretical framework for understanding LLMs' tolerance to position perturbations

title: PLAY2PROMPT: Zero-shot Tool Instruction Optimization for LLM Agents via Tool Play
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly integrated with specialized
external tools, yet many tasks demand zero-shot tool usage with minimal or
noisy documentation. Existing solutions rely on manual rewriting or labeled
data for validation, making them inapplicable in true zero-shot settings. To
address these challenges, we propose PLAY2PROMPT, an automated framework that
systematically "plays" with each tool to explore its input-output behaviors.
Through this iterative trial-and-error process, PLAY2PROMPT refines tool
documentation and generates usage examples without any labeled data. These
examples not only guide LLM inference but also serve as validation to further
enhance tool utilization. Extensive experiments on real-world tasks demonstrate
that PLAY2PROMPT significantly improves zero-shot tool performance across both
open and closed models, offering a scalable and effective solution for
domain-specific tool integration.

AI.tldr: PLAY2PROMPT is an automated framework that improves zero-shot tool usage with large language models (LLMs) by iteratively exploring tools' input-output behaviors and refining documentation without labeled data.
AI.motivation: Existing approaches to zero-shot tool usage rely on manual rewriting or labeled data validation, which are not feasible in true zero-shot scenarios.
AI.method: PLAY2PROMPT systematically 'plays' with each tool through an iterative trial-and-error process to explore input-output behaviors, refine documentation, and generate usage examples without requiring labeled data.
AI.result: The framework significantly enhances zero-shot tool performance across various tasks and model types, demonstrating its effectiveness in domain-specific tool integration.
AI.conclusion: PLAY2PROMPT provides a scalable solution for improving the performance of LLMs when integrated with tools in a zero-shot context.
key_contributions: Automated exploration of tool behaviors without labeled data
Refinement of tool documentation through iterative play
Generated usage examples that enhance LLM inference and validation

title: IPA-CHILDES & G2P+: Feature-Rich Resources for Cross-Lingual Phonology and Phonemic Language Modeling
summary:
In this paper, we introduce two resources: (i) G2P+, a tool for converting
orthographic datasets to a consistent phonemic representation; and (ii) IPA
CHILDES, a phonemic dataset of child-centered speech across 31 languages. Prior
tools for grapheme-to-phoneme conversion result in phonemic vocabularies that
are inconsistent with established phonemic inventories, an issue which G2P+
addresses by leveraging the inventories in the Phoible database. Using this
tool, we augment CHILDES with phonemic transcriptions to produce IPA CHILDES.
This new resource fills several gaps in existing phonemic datasets, which often
lack multilingual coverage, spontaneous speech, and a focus on child-directed
language. We demonstrate the utility of this dataset for phonological research
by training phoneme language models on 11 languages and probing them for
distinctive features, finding that the distributional properties of phonemes
are sufficient to learn major class and place features cross-lingually.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces G2P+, a tool for converting orthographic datasets to phonemic representations, and IPA CHILDES, a new phonemic dataset of child-centered speech across 31 languages.
AI.motivation: To create consistent phonemic representations from orthographic datasets and to provide a phonemic dataset that addresses gaps in multilingual and spontaneous child-directed speech research.
AI.method: G2P+ leverages established phonemic inventories from the Phoible database to improve on prior grapheme-to-phoneme conversion tools, while IPA CHILDES is created by augmenting the existing CHILDES dataset with phonemic transcriptions.
AI.result: The utility of IPA CHILDES is demonstrated by training phoneme language models on 11 languages, revealing that the phonemic distributions can effectively learn major class and place features across languages.
AI.conclusion: IPA CHILDES represents a significant advance in phonological research, addressing limitations in existing phonemic datasets and providing valuable resources for linguistics and child language studies.
key_contributions: Introduction of G2P+ for accurate grapheme-to-phoneme conversion.
Creation of IPA CHILDES, a multilingual phonemic dataset for child-directed speech.
Demonstration of the efficacy of phonemic distributions in learning linguistic features across languages.

title: BabyLM's First Words: Word Segmentation as a Phonological Probing Task
summary:
Language models provide a key framework for studying linguistic theories
based on prediction, but phonological analysis using large language models
(LLMs) is difficult; there are few phonological benchmarks beyond English and
the standard input representation used in LLMs (subwords of graphemes) is not
suitable for analyzing the representation of phonemes. In this work, we
demonstrate how word segmentation can be used as a phonological probing task,
allowing us to study the representations learned by phoneme-based language
models trained on child-directed speech across 31 languages. Following
computational models of word segmentation, we present unsupervised methods for
extracting word boundaries from a trained model using the observation that
prediction-error peaks at the start of words. We also use linear probes to
identify that these models implicitly track word boundaries, even when they do
not appear in training. This cross-lingual work corroborates statistical
learning theories of acquisition and empirically motivates new methods for
training subword tokenizers.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a method for using word segmentation as a phonological probing task with phoneme-based language models trained on child-directed speech, demonstrating that these models can implicitly learn word boundaries across multiple languages.
AI.motivation: The study aims to address the limitations in phonological analysis using large language models (LLMs) and explore the representation of phonemes, as well as to advance methods for training subword tokenizers.
AI.method: The paper introduces unsupervised methods to extract word boundaries based on prediction-error peaks from a trained model, and employs linear probes to investigate the implicit tracking of word boundaries by language models.
AI.result: The findings indicate that phoneme-based language models effectively learn to track word boundaries without explicit training on them and support statistical learning theories of acquisition.
AI.conclusion: This work not only enhances understanding of phonological analysis in LLMs but also motivates novel approaches for the training of subword tokenizers, particularly in multilingual contexts.
key_contributions: Demonstration of word segmentation as a phonological probing task.
Unsupervised methods for word boundary extraction from LLMs.
Cross-lingual validation of statistical learning theories related to language acquisition.

title: Chain-of-Code Collapse: Reasoning Failures in LLMs via Adversarial Prompting in Code Generation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable success in tasks
requiring complex reasoning, such as code generation, mathematical problem
solving, and algorithmic synthesis -- especially when aided by reasoning tokens
and Chain-of-Thought prompting. Yet, a core question remains: do these models
truly reason, or do they merely exploit shallow statistical patterns? In this
paper, we introduce Chain-of-Code Collapse, where we systematically investigate
the robustness of reasoning LLMs by introducing a suite of semantically
faithful yet adversarially structured prompt perturbations. Our evaluation --
spanning 700 perturbed code generations derived from LeetCode-style problems --
applies transformations such as storytelling reframing, irrelevant constraint
injection, example reordering, and numeric perturbation. We observe that while
certain modifications severely degrade performance (with accuracy drops up to
-42.1%), others surprisingly improve model accuracy by up to 35.3%, suggesting
sensitivity not only to semantics but also to surface-level prompt dynamics.
These findings expose the fragility and unpredictability of current reasoning
systems, underscoring the need for more principles approaches to reasoning
alignments and prompting robustness. We release our perturbation datasets and
evaluation framework to promote further research in trustworthy and resilient
LLM reasoning.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the robustness of reasoning in Large Language Models (LLMs) using adversarial prompt perturbations, revealing their sensitivity to both semantics and surface dynamics, and calls for improved approaches to reasoning alignments.
AI.motivation: The study aims to understand if LLMs genuinely reason or simply exploit statistical patterns, particularly in complex tasks.
AI.method: The authors introduce the Chain-of-Code Collapse framework, evaluating 700 perturbed code generations from LeetCode-style problems with various perturbations such as storytelling reframing and numerical perturbations.
AI.result: Certain modifications led to accuracy drops of up to 42.1%, whereas other perturbations surprisingly increased accuracy by up to 35.3%, indicating sensitivity to prompt dynamics and semantics.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight the fragility of current LLM reasoning systems and advocate for improved robust reasoning approaches.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Chain-of-Code Collapse evaluation framework
Release of perturbation datasets for further research
Demonstration of sensitivity of LLMs to prompt dynamics and semantics
AI.limitations: The study focuses on a limited set of transformation types for prompt perturbations.

title: Improving Fairness of Large Language Models in Multi-document Summarization
summary:
Fairness in multi-document summarization (MDS) is crucial for providing
comprehensive views across documents with diverse social attribute values,
which can significantly impact decision-making. For example, a summarization
system that tends to overrepresent negative reviews of products can mislead
customers into disregarding good products. Previous works measure fairness in
MDS at two levels: summary-level and corpus-level. While summary-level fairness
focuses on individual summaries, corpus-level fairness focuses on a corpus of
summaries. Recent methods primarily focus on summary-level fairness. We propose
FairPO, a preference tuning method that focuses on both summary-level and
corpus-level fairness in MDS. To improve summary-level fairness, we propose to
generate preference pairs by perturbing document sets. To improve corpus-level
fairness, we propose fairness-aware preference tuning by dynamically adjusting
the weights of preference pairs. Our experiments show that FairPO outperforms
strong baselines while maintaining the critical qualities of summaries. The

title: Towards Large Language Models with Self-Consistent Natural Language Explanations
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) seem to offer an easy path to interpretability:
just ask them to explain their decisions. Yet, studies show that these post-hoc
explanations often misrepresent the true decision process, as revealed by
mismatches in feature importance. Despite growing evidence of this
inconsistency, no systematic solutions have emerged, partly due to the high
cost of estimating feature importance, which limits evaluations to small
datasets. To address this, we introduce the Post-hoc Self-Consistency Bank
(PSCB) - a large-scale benchmark of decisions spanning diverse tasks and
models, each paired with LLM-generated explanations and corresponding feature
importance scores. Analysis of PSCB reveals that self-consistency scores barely
differ between correct and incorrect predictions. We also show that the
standard metric fails to meaningfully distinguish between explanations. To
overcome this limitation, we propose an alternative metric that more
effectively captures variation in explanation quality. We use it to fine-tune
LLMs via Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), leading to significantly better
alignment between explanations and decision-relevant features, even under
domain shift. Our findings point to a scalable path toward more trustworthy,
self-consistent LLMs.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses the challenges of interpreting large language models (LLMs) by presenting the Post-hoc Self-Consistency Bank (PSCB), a benchmark that pairs LLM-generated explanations with feature importance scores, highlighting issues with current explanation metrics and offering a new metric for improved alignment.
AI.motivation: To tackle the limitations of existing post-hoc explanation methods for LLMs, particularly the inconsistency in feature importance, and to provide a scalable solution for trustworthy model interpretability.
AI.method: Introduced the Post-hoc Self-Consistency Bank (PSCB) as a benchmark containing diverse tasks and models, each with LLM-generated explanations and feature importance scores, analyzed explanation metrics, and developed an alternative metric to fine-tune LLMs through Direct Preference Optimization (DPO).
AI.result: The analysis showed that self-consistency scores do not effectively differentiate between correct and incorrect predictions, and that the proposed alternative metric improved the alignment of explanations with decision-relevant features, even when models faced domain shifts.
AI.conclusion: The newly proposed metric provides a pathway toward more reliable and consistent explanations from LLMs, contributing to enhanced model trustworthiness and interpretability.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Post-hoc Self-Consistency Bank (PSCB) benchmark.
Development of a new metric for evaluating explanation quality in LLMs.
Method to fine-tune LLMs through Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) for better explanation alignment.
AI.limitations: The proposed solutions still require extensive evaluation across more diverse datasets to ensure generalizability and robustness.
